node.title: Ed Sheeran wins 'Shape of You' copyright case
node.description: A judge ruled that the singer-songwriter had not plagiarised the 2015 song 'Oh Why' by Sami Chokri. Video

node.title: Eleven-year-old driver among nine youths caught after ram raid at Auckland dairy
node.description: Nine young people - including an 11-year-old driver - have been caught after a dairy in Auckland was ram-raided early this morning.

node.title: Three more ways NZ can add to global pressure on Russia
node.description: Opinion - New Zealand should offer lethal military assistance to Ukraine, reduce the size of the Russian ambassador's office, and help hold war criminals accountable, law professor Alexander Gillespie…

node.title: Commission rejects bid for extra Māori seat on TRC
node.description: A late push for Taranaki Regional Council to have two Māori seats at this year's elections has failed.

node.title: Police launch homicide inquiry after death of woman in her 60s
node.description: The death of a woman who was found at a property in Christchurch is being treated as a homicide.

node.title: Highway between Tokomaru Bay and Te Puia Springs reopens
node.description: The final section of State Highway 35 in Tairāwhiti, north of Gisborne, that was closed by last month's severe weather event reopens to all traffic tomorrow.

node.title: KiwiRail operator reached for phone before locomotive fell into the sea - investigation
node.description: An investigation has found a KiwiRail employee thought he had applied the brakes on a remote-controlled shunt locomotive and went to make a call on his phone, before the engine fell into the sea.

node.title: British PM: Transgender women should not compete in female events
node.description: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson says transgender women should not be competing in female sporting events.

node.title: New Zealand announces fresh sanctions on Russia
node.description: All Russian imports to New Zealand will be hit with a 35 percent tariff in response to what our government has described as "abhorrent and reprehensible" atrocities committed against Ukrainian… Audio

node.title: National, Act urged to reconsider Māori Health Authority stance
node.description: The Cancer Society and a number of NGOs have penned an open letter urging National and Act leaders to rethink their stance on scrapping the Māori Health Authority.

node.title: Justice may wait while world gathers evidence of Russia's crimes in Ukraine
node.description: Analysis - The legal noose is tightening around Russia, with international investigations under way into its invasion of Ukraine, writes Jane Patterson.

node.title: 'Our sanctions at the moment are relatively weak' - Luxon
node.description: The leader of the National Party wants to the government to take more and stronger action against Russia over the war in Ukraine and be more in step with actions taken by the US, UK and Australia. Audio

node.title: Kinder Surprise chocolate eggs recalled over salmonella fears
node.description: There have been cases of illnesses linked to the eggs overseas, but so far none in this country, MPI says.

node.title: Dr McElnay on NZ's Covid response: 'Sharing information was key'
node.description: The outgoing Director of Public Health says the quick sharing of scientific data and the widespread use of masks have been critical parts of NZ's public health response. Watch today's Covid-19… Video

node.title: SFO ends two-year probe of donations to Auckland mayor's election campaigns
node.description: No action will be taken over the way donations were used during two of Phil Goff's mayoral campaigns.

node.title: NZ Rugby refs boss believes red card round a 'one-off'
node.description: Bryce Lawrence believes the rash of red cards in round seven of Super Rugby Pacific was a "one-off" and the average this season is likely to be no higher than previous years.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 13 further deaths, 639 in hospital, 11,634 new cases
node.description: There have been 11,634 new community cases of Covid-19 reported today, with 13 further deaths - including three people in their 30s - and 639 people in hospital.

node.title: Fire crews, helicopters resume efforts to control Awarua blaze
node.description: Six fire crews and six helicopters have continued working to control a large fire south of Invercargill today.

node.title: Australia-New Zealand refugee resettlement deal: What you need to know
node.description: Explainer - What is the Australia New Zealand refugee resettlement deal and why has it been agreed after nearly a decade? RNZ is here to clear it all up.

node.title: Dunedin protesters occupying Octagon told to leave by Monday
node.description: A group of anti-mandate protesters who have been camping in Dunedin's Octagon for almost two months have been formally told to leave by Monday.

node.title: Police homicide inquiry finds Gisborne woman was shot dead
node.description: Police have confirmed Gisborne woman Maraea Smith died after being shot on Friday 25 March.

node.title: Police homocide inquiry finds Gisborne woman was shot dead
node.description: Police have confirmed Gisborne woman Maraea Smith died after being shot on Friday 25 March.

node.title: Covid-19: Home testing may miss 50% of positive cases
node.description: A University of Auckland epidemiologist wants pharmacies to be doing RATs, to improve the accuracy of tests and better capture the results.

node.title: Dunedin council moves in on protesters occupying Octagon
node.description: The Dunedin City Council wants the anti-mandate protesters camped out in the city's Octagon to leave, saying their cause has now run its course.

node.title: NZ woolgrowers among sectors hit by China's Covid-19 restrictions
node.description: A resurgence of Covid-19 within China is causing headaches for some primary sector exporters, with lockdown measures disrupting economic activity and slowing down distribution networks.

node.title: Two men allegedly impersonated federal agents to get access to Secret Service
node.description: The two allegedly used fake credentials to get closer to members of federal law enforcement agencies, including Secret Service agents assigned to the first lady.

node.title: Healthy drinks in schools plan goes out for consultation
node.description: Water, milk and milk alternatives: the government is seeking feedback on a plan to ban all other drinks from primary schools to keep children healthy.

node.title: Mortgage applications fall as economic uncertainty bites
node.description: With borrowers feeling the pinch, consumer credit demand is down 9 percent in the year to March, and mortgage applications fell 19 percent, data from Centrix shows.

node.title: Silence over why mall attacker's request to leave NZ ignored
node.description: Government agencies which battled to detain and deport the LynnMall attacker Ahamed Samsudeen are remaining silent on why they did not agree to his request to lose New Zealand residence.

node.title: Kaikōura businesses wait for tourists to return: 'We know we'll get there'
node.description: Kaikōura businesses are remaining optimistic about the future despite the return of tourists predicted to still be months away.
